LG-FedAvgÂ outperforms FedAvgÂ and MTL under local test and achieves similar performance under new test while using around 50%percent5050\% of the total parameters, and outperforms all using the same number of parameters. Mean and standard deviation are computed over 101010 runs.

references: The results in TableÂ 1 show that LG-FedAvgÂ gives strong performance with low communication cost. For CIFAR local test, LG-FedAvgÂ significantly outperforms FedAvgÂ since local models allow us to better model the local device data distribution. For new test, LG-FedAvgÂ achieves similar performance to FedAvgÂ while using around 50%percent5050\% of the total parameters, and better performance with the same number of parameters. LG-FedAvgÂ also outperforms using local models only and local models trained with multitask learning (MTL). This shows that our end-to-end training strategy for local and global models is particularly suitable for large neural networks. We show MNIST results and sensitivity analysis wrt data and model splits in AppendixÂ C.2 and find similar observations.

Details: We adapt the baseline model from [1] without norm I image channel embeddings. We also substitute the VGGNetÂ [49] used in the original baseline model with a pre-trained ResNet-18Â [22]. Finally we use the deep LSTMÂ [23] embedding, which is an LSTM that consists of two hidden layers. For the LG-FedAvgÂ method, the global model uses the two final fully connected layers of the image and question channels, as well as the the additional two fully connected layers following the fusion via element-wise multiplication. The global model reduces the number of parameters to 9.53%percent9.539.53\% (5149200/540425725149200540425725149200/54042572). We use 50 devices and set number of local epochs E=1ğ¸1E=1, local minibatch size B=100ğµ100B=100, fraction of devices sampled per round C=0.1ğ¶0.1C=0.1. To train and evaluate our models, we use the data from the following: https://visualqa.org/download.html. TableÂ 10 shows a table of hyperparameters used, which strictly follows the baseline model from [1]. We first trained the best FedAvgÂ model and used the exact same hyperparamters to train LG-FedAvgÂ as well.

Details: For method 1, FedAvg, we train the global model and global adversary for 505050 outer epochs, within which the number of local epochs E=10ğ¸10E=10. For methods 2 and 3 involving local models, we begin by pre-training the local models and local adversaries for 101010 epochs before joint local and global training for 10 epochs. TableÂ 11 shows the table of all hyperparameters used. Experiments were run 10 times with the same hyperparameters but different random seeds. We aimed to keep the local, global, and adversary models as similar as possible between the three baselines for fair comparison. Apart from the number of local and global epochs all hyperparameters were kept the same from the tutorial https://blog.godatadriven.com/fairness-in-ml and associated code https://github.com/equialgo/fairness-in-ml. The data can be found at https://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/datasets/Adult.

references: Visual Question Answering (VQA): VQA is a large-scale multimodal benchmark with 0.250.250.25M images, 0.760.760.76M questions, and 101010M answersÂ [1]. We split the dataset in a non-i.i.d. manner and evaluate the accuracy under the local test setting. We use LSTMÂ [23] and ResNet-18Â [22] unimodal encoders as our local models and a global model which performs early fusionÂ [32] of text and image features for answer prediction. In Table 2, we observe that LG-FedAvgÂ reaches a goal accuracy of 40%percent4040\% while requiring lower communication costs (more VQA results and details in AppendixÂ C.2.3).

Catastrophic forgetting, unless one fine-tunes again on training devices and incur high communication cost. LG-FedAvgÂ relieves catastrophic forgetting by using local models to perform well on both online rotated and regular MNIST, with (C=0.1)ğ¶0.1(C=0.1) and without (C=0.0)ğ¶0.0(C=0.0) fine-tuning.

references: Results: We report results in TableÂ 3 and observe that: 1) FedAvgÂ suffers from catastrophic forgettingÂ [48] without fine-tuning (C=0.0ğ¶0.0C=0.0), in which the global model can perform well on the new deviceâ€™s rotated MNIST (92%)percent92(92\%) but completely forgets how to classify regular MNIST (32%)percent32(32\%). Only after fine-tuning (C=0.1ğ¶0.1C=0.1) does the performance on both regular and rotated MNIST improve, but this requires more communication over the 100100100 devices. 2) LG-FedAvgÂ with local models relieves catastrophic forgetting. Augmenting local models indeed helps to improve online performance on rotated MNIST (93%)percent93(93\%) while allowing the global model to retain performance on regular MNIST (97%)percent97(97\%), outperforming both FedAvgÂ and FedProx. We believe LG-FedAvgÂ achieves these results by learning a strong local representation that requires fewer updates from the trained global model.

references: Results: We report results according to: 1) classifier binary accuracy, 2) classifier ROC AUC score, and 3) adversary ROC AUC score. The classifier metrics should be as close to 100%percent100100\% as possible while the adversary should be as close to 50%percent5050\% as possible. From TableÂ 4, LG-FedAvg++Adv learns fair local representations that are unable to predict protected attributes (âˆ¼50%similar-toabsentpercent50\sim 50\% adversary AUC) with only a small drop in global accuracy (âˆ¼4%)similar-toabsentpercent4(\sim 4\%). In order to ensure that poor adversary AUC was indeed due to fair representations instead of a poorly trained adversary, we train a post-fit classifier from local representations to protected attributes and achieve similar random results.

references: Details: In all our experiments, we train with number of local epochs E=1ğ¸1E=1 and local minibatch size B=10ğµ10B=10. We set C=0.1ğ¶0.1C=0.1. Images were normalized prior to training and testing. In our experiments, we take the last two layers to form our global model, reducing the number of parameters to 15.79%percent15.7915.79\% (99,978/633,2269997863322699,978/633,226). TableÂ 5 shows the of hyperparameters used. The dataset can be found here: http://yann.lecun.com/exdb/mnist/. We train LG-FedAvgÂ with global updates until we reach a goal accuracy (97.5%percent97.597.5\% for MNIST) before training for additional rounds to jointly update local and global models. Our results are averaged over 10 runs. # FedAvg and LG Rounds are rounded to the nearest multiple of 5, which we use to calculate the number of parameters communicated. Standard deviations are also reported.

Details: We train with number of local epochs E=1ğ¸1E=1 and local minibatch size B=50ğµ50B=50. We set C=0.1ğ¶0.1C=0.1. Images are randomly cropped to size 323232, randomly flipped horizontally with probability p=0.5ğ‘0.5p=0.5, resized to 224Ã—224224224224\times 224, and normalized. For our model architecture, we chose Lenet-5. We use the two convolutional layers for the global model in our LG-FedAvgÂ method to minimize the number of parameters. We therefore reduce the number of parameters to 4.48%percent4.484.48\% (2872/641022872641022872/64102). TableÂ 5 shows a table of additional hyperparameters used. The dataset can be found here: https://www.cs.toronto.edu/~kriz/cifar.html. We train LG-FedAvgÂ with global updates until we reach a goal accuracy (57%percent5757\% for CIFAR-10) before training for additional rounds to jointly update local and global models. Our results are averaged over 10 runs and we report standard deviations. # FedAvg and LG Rounds are rounded to the nearest multiple of 5, which we use to calculate the number of parameters communicated.

references: Details: For method 1, FedAvg, we train the global model and global adversary for 505050 outer epochs, within which the number of local epochs E=10ğ¸10E=10. For methods 2 and 3 involving local models, we begin by pre-training the local models and local adversaries for 101010 epochs before joint local and global training for 10 epochs. TableÂ 11 shows the table of all hyperparameters used. Experiments were run 10 times with the same hyperparameters but different random seeds. We aimed to keep the local, global, and adversary models as similar as possible between the three baselines for fair comparison. Apart from the number of local and global epochs all hyperparameters were kept the same from the tutorial https://blog.godatadriven.com/fairness-in-ml and associated code https://github.com/equialgo/fairness-in-ml. The data can be found at https://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/datasets/Adult.
